articles.headline: As Court Clears Path, Chrysler Is Set to Exit Bankruptcy
articles.snippet: The United States Supreme Court declined to hear a challenge to the Chrysler bankruptcy settlement, clearing the way for the sale of Chrysler’s key assets to a group led by Fiat.
articles.abstract: The United States Supreme Court declined to hear a challenge to the Chrysler bankruptcy settlement, clearing the way for the sale of Chrysler’s key assets to a group led by Fiat.
articles.lead_paragraph: Chrysler appeared poised to emerge from bankruptcy by early Wednesday after the United States Supreme Court declined on Tuesday to hear a challenge by three Indiana state funds and several consumer groups to the sale of most of its assets to Fiat.
articles.byline: By Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Michigan Works to Remake Itself Without King Auto
articles.snippet: As the state hemorrhages jobs, lawmakers and executives are seeking alternative industries — like filmmaking and solar panel production — to take up the slack.
articles.abstract: As the state hemorrhages jobs, lawmakers and executives are seeking alternative industries — like filmmaking and solar panel production — to take up the slack.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  The former General Motors Centerpoint truck plant in Pontiac, Mich., is another empty building that served for years as a reminder of the declining fortunes of American automakers.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Nick Bunkley

articles.headline: College in Need Closes a Door to Needy Students
articles.snippet: Because of the recession, Reed College in Oregon, known for academic rigor and a free-spirited student body, has had to make budget cuts and reject some needy applicants.
articles.abstract: Because of the recession, Reed College in Oregon, known for academic rigor and a free-spirited student body, has had to make budget cuts and reject some needy applicants.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTLAND, Ore.  The admissions team at Reed College, known for its free-spirited students, learned in March that the prospective freshman class it had so carefully composed after weeks of reviewing essays, scores and recommendations was unworkable.

articles.headline: Battle to Halt Graft Scourge in Africa Ebbs
articles.snippet: Experts and prosecutors say they fear that major setbacks to anticorruption efforts in Africa’s most pivotal nations are weakening the resolve to fight.
articles.abstract: Experts and prosecutors say they fear that major setbacks to anticorruption efforts in Africa’s most pivotal nations are weakening the resolve to fight.
articles.lead_paragraph: LUSAKA, Zambia  The fight against corruption in Africa’s most pivotal nations is faltering as public agencies investigating wrongdoing by powerful politicians have been undermined or disbanded and officials leading the charge have been dismissed, subjected to death threats and driven into exile.

articles.headline: America’s Sea of Red Ink Was Years in the Making
articles.snippet: In the debate about how the government racked up so much debt, there is enough blame to go around.
articles.abstract: In the debate about how the government racked up so much debt, there is enough blame to go around.
articles.lead_paragraph: There are two basic truths about the enormous deficits that the federal government will run in the coming years.

articles.headline: Smartphone Rises Fast From Gadget to Necessity
articles.snippet: The increasing popularity of BlackBerrys, iPhones and their kin owes as much to sociology as technology.
articles.abstract: The increasing popularity of BlackBerrys, iPhones and their kin owes as much to sociology as technology.
articles.lead_paragraph: In today’s recession-racked economy, penny-pinching is a national pastime. But people are still opening their wallets for smartphones.

articles.headline: Magazine Researchers Explore New Ways to Weigh Ad Impact
articles.snippet: When advertisers assess a magazine’s reach, they rely on the results of door-to-door surveys. New services intend to update that model.
articles.abstract: When advertisers assess a magazine’s reach, they rely on the results of door-to-door surveys. New services intend to update that model.
articles.lead_paragraph: On television, advertisers pay based on the ratings of a particular commercial. On the Internet, they pay according to a measurement like a click on an ad. And in magazines, advertisers choose where to run ads based on the results of door-to-door surveys done twice a year.

articles.headline: Treasury to Set Executives’ Pay at 7 Ailing Firms
articles.snippet: A federal proposal to restrict executive pay has the potential to humble seven large institutions that have received billions of dollars in bailout money.
articles.abstract: A federal proposal to restrict executive pay has the potential to humble seven large institutions that have received billions of dollars in bailout money.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Obama administration’s sweeping new proposal to restrict executive pay is likely to be a humbling exercise for seven of the nation’s largest companies, which have received billions of dollars in federal assistance to survive the economic crisis.
